Review Rare earth-incorporated high entropy oxides for energy and environmental catalysis Yuou Li a b Ke Wang a b Xiaomei Wang a b Zijian Wang a b Jing Xu a b Meng Zhao a b Xiao Wang a b * Shuyan Song a b * Hongjie Zhang a b c * a State Key Laboratory of Rare Earth Resource Utilization, Changchun Institute of Applied Chemistry, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Changchun 130022, Jilin, China State Key Laboratory of Rare Earth Resource Utilization Changchun Institute of Applied Chemistry Chinese Academy of Sciences Changchun Jilin 130022 China State Key Laboratory of Rare Earth Resource Utilization, Changchun Institute of Applied Chemistry, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Changchun 130022, Jilin, China b School of Applied Chemistry and Engineering, University of Science and Technology of China, Hefei 230026, Anhui, China School of Applied Chemistry and Engineering University of Science and Technology of China Hefei Anhui 230026 China School of Applied Chemistry and Engineering, University of Science and Technology of China, Hefei 230026, Anhui, China c Department of Chemistry, Tsinghua University, Beijing 100084, China Department of Chemistry Tsinghua University Beijing 100084 China Department of Chemistry, Tsinghua University, Beijing 100084, China * Corresponding author. High entropy oxides have been regarded as one of the most promising catalysts. Their unique and diverse elemental compositions bring stable structures and abundant metal active sites to the catalysts. Notably, rare earth ions have similar radii, unique electron orbitals, and variable valence states. As a result, incorporating rare earth elements into high entropy oxides can effectively adjust the surface state of the catalyst, ultimately improving the structure and properties of the high entropy oxides. However, there is no systematic review on the development of rare earth-incorporated high entropy oxides. In this review, we target the structure, synthesis, and application of rare earth-incorporated high entropy oxides to summarize their research progress in catalysis in recent years. First, we provide an overview of three types of rare earth-incorporated high entropy oxides: fluorite-type, perovskite-type, and pyrochlore-type. Then, the main synthesis methods are discussed in detail, including solid-state reaction, nebulized spray pyrolysis, chemical co-precipitation, and solution combustion. Finally, we analyze the applications of this material in catalytic reactions and suggest possible challenges and solution strategies. It is concluded that this unique material has good prospects for development. Graphical Abstract We systematically summarize the typical structures and synthetic methods of rare earth-incorporated high entropy oxides. The review focuses on their applications in three major catalytic fields. Furthermore, we discuss the challenges and coping strategies for this emerging material and provide an outlook for its future development. Keywords Rare earth High entropy oxides Catalysis Single-phase structure Synthesis 1 Introduction In recent decades, the rapid development of industrial production and technology has resulted in increasingly severe energy and environmental problems, such as global warming and air pollution, which have significantly impacted the planet, endangering human life and economic development [1–3]. Renewable energy is a crucial focus for researchers as it can significantly aid in the transformation of society’s energy systems [4,5]. In addition to the development of energy sources, the elimination of toxic and hazardous substances from the environment is also of high research value. Catalytic technology receives particular attention due to its great potential for pollutant removal and energy conversion [6–8]. For instance, photocatalytic water decomposition technology can facilitate the conversion of solar energy into hydrogen energy [9–11]. Catalytic oxidation of CO is capable of converting toxic gases into CO2, which can then be catalytically hydrogenated to achieve the rational use of greenhouse gases [12–15]. The catalytic process mainly relies on selecting and designing catalytic materials to enhance the reactivity. In catalysis research, metallic materials have considerable application potential due to their ability to accelerate the reaction process at lower temperatures and to promote product generation selectively [16]. High entropy oxides (HEOs), a new metallic material, were discovered by Rost et al. [17] for the first time in 2015. It is a single-phase with a multi-component solid solution driven by configurational entropy. The chemical complexity of the material attracted the attention of researchers. In the following decade, the application of HEOs catalytic materials has continuously emerged. These materials exhibit high catalytic activity and stability due to the composition of multiple active metals and easily modified properties (e.g., redox capacity, high thermal stability) [18–21]. HEOs typically consist of five or more equimolar metal elements and are uniformly distributed in a random manner in a single lattice (Fig. 1(a) ). Entropy is widely recognized as the driving force for single-phase stabilization of HEOs and is an essential factor that affects thermodynamic stability [22]. As per statistical thermodynamics, the entropy value is higher when a system contains more microstates and components. Consequently, the Gibbs free energy (ΔG mix = ΔH mix – TΔS mix) is lower. In most cases, equimolar amounts of the five cations increase the conformational entropy of the system (S config = RlnN ≥ 1.5R), where N is the number of components in the system [19,23]. This lowers the Gibbs free energy, leading to stable single-phase structural HEOs. Through the analysis and research on the composition of different metal elements, many high entropy oxides with different crystal structures have been discovered, including but not limited to perovskite, fluorite, rock salt, and spinel (Fig. 1(c)) [24]. The lattice distortion generated in the formation of specific structures promotes the activation and transport of active substances, favorably forming oxygen defects, thereby enhancing the performance of various catalytic reactions (Fig. 1(b)) [25,26]. Moreover, the charge distortion generated between metals with different valence states and oxygen can be a crucial factor affecting the catalytic reactivity [27]. Therefore, researchers continue to explore and innovate with the aim of enriching the theoretical system of HEOs. In recent years, rare earth oxide materials have attracted much attention in the field of catalysis and have achieved abundant research results. Rare earth elements (REs) play a crucial role in the modification of structures and properties due to the unfilled 4f electron orbital, which can produce a range of electronic energy levels and form chemically stable metal compounds [28,29]. This positive effect on the formation of multi-component HEOs is seen in both structural and surface properties. Most HEOs successfully prepared as single-phase are within the 15% limit of atomic radii differences [30], and REs exhibit highly similar ionic radii and physicochemical properties, which meet this qualification. Moreover, variable oxidation states of REs, such as Ce3+/Ce4+, can facilitate specific catalytic reactions by increasing oxygen storage and release capacity through the redox process. Therefore, researchers are increasingly trying to synthesize rare earth-incorporated high entropy oxides (RE-HEOs) for catalytic studies to improve the structure and performance of these catalysts. Rare earth metal ions play a crucial role in the formation of unique structural features due to their various coordination forms [31]. In particular, RE-HEOs can be mainly divided into perovskite-type, fluorite-type, and pyrochlore-type as fluorite-derived structures. At present, some breakthroughs and progress in studies on RE-HEOs have been made in the field of catalysis. More comprehensive theoretical construction is believed to be achieved in future studies. This review summarizes the unique structural and synthetic strategies of RE-HEOs, with a focus on outlining their recent research progress in energy and environmental catalysis. We describe in detail the structural characteristics of RE-HEOs, such as perovskite-type, fluorite-type, and pyrochlore-type. Numerous studies have demonstrated that the multi-component high entropy effect enables combinations of different metals to form single-phase structures. Moreover, even non-equimolar metal compositions can be used to form HEOs, which is a breakthrough for studying RE-HEOs. Notably, the selection and optimization of synthetic methods are crucial for the establishment of high entropy systems. More simple and rapid synthetic methods are being applied to prepare such materials, replacing time-consuming and labor-intensive synthesis processes. Among many synthesis methods, we focus on the solid-state reaction method (SRM), nebulized spray pyrolysis (NSP), chemical co-precipitation synthesis (CCS), and solution combustion synthesis (SCS). We further introduce the application progress of RE-HEOs in electrocatalysis, thermocatalysis, and photocatalysis. The effects of this multi-element tunable material on the reactivity are described in detail. Finally, the challenges faced by RE-HEOs and the possible strategies to address them are discussed in order to establish a theoretical system for this emerging high entropy system. This review aims to provide a systematic summary of RE-HEOs, which could have far-reaching implications for their future research and development. 2 Structure types of RE-HEOs HEOs are rich in adjustable constituent elements, have a well-defined crystal structure, and are structurally stable in a single solid solution. At the same time, HEOs also have the “four core effects”: the high entropy effect, delayed diffusion effect, lattice distortion effect, and cocktail effect [32,33]. These excellent structural properties enable them to have excellent high-temperature resistance, strong mechanical stability, corrosion resistance, and other properties superior to most traditional metal materials. It has great potential for application in catalytic reactions. The research found that the three most common crystal structures of RE-HEOs are perovskite-type, fluorite-type, and pyrochlore-type, each of which has specific elemental categories and lattice characteristics (Fig. 2 ). These three structures are summarized in detail below. 2.1 Perovskite-type high entropy oxides Perovskite-type high entropy oxides (P-HEOs) have a general molecular formula of ABO3 and typically have cubic crystal structures [34]. The cubic perovskite oxide structure can be viewed as the main body of the skeleton composed of BO6 octahedra through a point-sharing arrangement, while the A ion occupies the center of the gap surrounded by eight BO6 octahedra [35]. Rare earth or alkaline-earth metal elements with large radii (La, Ce, Ca, Sr, etc.) usually occupy the A-site in the lattice of perovskite oxides, while transition metal elements with small radii (Fe, Co, Ni, Cr, Mn, Zn, Cu, etc.) occupy the B-site. In recent years, studies of P-HEOs have focused on the composition of equimolar elements at the B-site and obtaining single-phase crystal structures. For example, Chen et al. [36] designed and synthesized pure-phase La(FeCoNiCrMn)O3, and the X-ray diffraction (XRD) image shows that the sample has a simple cubic crystal structure (Fig. 3(a) ). All transition metal elements are well dispersed in the B-site of the perovskite oxide lattice. The randomness of polymetallic systems makes it easier to form a high entropy phase. Notably, non-equimolar high entropy systems have also been reported. Nguyen et al. [37] studied non-equimolar La-based P-HEOs by doubling the molar ratio of each metal at the B-site respectively to obtain a series of P-HEOs with components similar to La(CrMnFeCo2Ni)O3. The prepared P-HEOs are all single-phase orthorhombic perovskite oxide structures formed when the tolerance factor t < 0.8 (Fig. 3(b)). In this structure, the B-site ions occupy the cell center, the O ion occupies the face center, and the A-site ions occupy the vertex position [38]. However, the presence of a small impurity phase in the monometallic perovskite oxide LaCrO3 demonstrates that the stable single-phase crystal structure is largely dependent on high configurational entropy under multi-element mixing [39]. Not only can the B-site have a multi-element composite, Sarkar et al. [40] first reported P-HEOs containing 5+5 cations (Gd0.2La0.2Nd0.2Sm0.2Y0.2)(Co0.2Cr0.2Fe0.2Mn0.2Ni0.2)O3, which is capable of forming single-phase orthorhombic crystal structure. Consequently, entropy-driven formation of stable single-phase structure is well demonstrated in HEOs. In addition, there is a common variant structure for perovskite oxide, A2BO4, which can crystallize into two different structures: the T phase and the T’ phase. In the T phase structure, the perovskite (ABO3) and the rock salt layer (AO) are stacked alternately along the C-axis with octahedral coordination of the B-site cations. In the T’ phase structure, the A2O2 fluorite layer and the BO2 sheet are alternately stacked along the C-axis, while the B-site cations are in tetrahedral coordination. However, studies on this variant in HEOs are scarce. Zhao et al. [41] synthesized A2BO4-type HEOs (La0.2Pr0.2Nd0.2Sm0.2Gd0.2)2CuO4 with a single tetrahedral phase structure in the T’ configuration for the first time and successfully applied it to SOFC cathodes. 2.2 Fluorite-type high entropy oxides Fluorite-type high entropy oxide (F-HEOs), the molecular formula of (REs/Metals)O2–δ , is generally dominated by REs [42]. The overall structure belongs to the cubic crystal system, which is based on the formation of face-centered dense stacks of cations whose tetrahedral interstitial positions are filled by anions (oxygen) [43]. In 2017, Sarkar et al. [44] reported the multi-component oxides containing 3–6 REs (Ce, La, Nd, Pr, Sm, Y), and all samples show a single-phase fluorite structure (Fig. 3(c)). However, a small amount of secondary phase is present under the 7-component system, probably owing to its slow diffusion due to the increased number of cations competing for the same position in the lattice [45]. Moreover, F-HEOs with an average cation radius larger than Ce4+ will have an increased lattice parameter compared to CeO2. However, binary rare earth oxides have a mixed-phase structure, proving the role of entropy in stabilizing the single-phase structure. In addition to the ability of entropy, the presence of Ce4+ was also found to contribute to the stabilization of the single-phase structure. Okejiri et al. [46] reported a single-phase F-HEOs CeHfZrSnErO x formed by diffusion of smaller cations (Hf4+, Zr4+, Sn4+, and Er3+) into the CeO2-based lattice. The XRD image of CeHfZrSnErO x shows a cubic fluorite structure whose characteristic reflections are located at slightly higher 2θ angles than CeO2, consistent with the introduction of smaller radii cations leading to a decrease in lattice parameters (Fig. 3(d)). The single-phase F-HEOs structure is still maintained under heat treatment of loaded precious metals, indicating its high thermal stability property. 2.3 Pyrochlore-type high entropy oxides The pyrochlore-type high entropy oxides, as the variant of the fluorite structure, have the general molecular formula A2B2O7 [47]. Half of the 8-coordination cations are replaced by 6-coordination octahedrons to form a face-centered cubic structure, and the cell is enlarged by a factor of 2. Guo et al. [48] reported a series of A2Ti2O7 (A: the combination of Gd, Dy, Ho, Er, Yb, and Nd) and found that the multi-component systems were all pyrochlore single-phase structures (Fig. 3(e)). Conventional A2B2O7 structure is closely related to the cation radii ratio of A-site and B-site (r A/r B). The crystal structure of pyrochlore is present when r A/r B ranges from 1.46 to 1.78, changes to a disordered fluorite structure when r A/r B < 1.46, and a layered monoclinic perovskite structure is formed when r A/r B > 1.78 [49]. However, the r A/r B ratio of Gd2(Ti0.25Zr0.25Hf0.25Ce0.25)2O7 prepared by Wang et al. is 1.4499, which is no longer limited by the r A/r B [50]. In the multi-component high entropy system, a shift of the diffraction peaks to the lower angle can be observed in XRD, indicating that the solid solution atoms have succeeded in entering the lattice to a certain extent. There is a lattice distortion effect in the HEOs, which leads to lattice expansion (Fig. 3(f)). More microstates in lattice-expanded solid solutions lead to an increase in the entropy of the system, which causes a decrease in the free energy and prevents the material phase separation from achieving single-phase stability [51,52]. 2.4 Structural influences on performance The structural features of RE-HEOs have a significant impact on catalytic reactions. The M–O bonds in their structures can directly participate in the catalytic reactions by creating oxygen vacancies that form central sites for adsorption and activation of reactive molecules. For example, solid solutions created by adding multiple metal cations to the CeO2 lattice can generate abundant oxygen vacancies and reactive oxygen species, which play a crucial role in redox [53]. Additionally, the “four core effects” of high entropy materials are effective. The high entropy effect ensures the formation of single-phase solid solutions and catalytic stability at high temperatures. The lattice distortion effect leads to the formation of active sites, such as oxygen vacancies, which enhances the catalytic activity. The delayed diffusion of ions resulting from the complex and varied crystal structure is responsible for the excellent stability of high entropy materials in catalysis [54]. Finally, the cocktail effect demonstrates the synergistic effect of multiple elements in high entropy oxides to promote catalytic performance [55]. In addition to the advantages brought by the structural effect, the differences in morphological structures also have different impacts on enhancing the catalytic performance. For example, porous structures can increase the contact area between the catalyst and the reaction phase, allowing for better charge transfer. This makes them excellent for electrocatalytic applications. When combined with other components, HEOs form a heterogeneous structure that can synergistically enhance catalytic activity and stability at the interface [56]. Loading HEOs with low concentrations of noble metals can improve catalytic activity and thermal stability simultaneously. Therefore, the unique structural features of HEOs are decisive factors in their catalytic ability. 3 Synthesis methods of RE-HEOs Rost et al. [17] were the first to use a solid-state reaction method (SRM) to synthesize single-phase HEOs bulk materials. The method involved mixing and milling equimolar NiO, CoO, ZnO, MgO, CuO, and 3 mm-diameter Y-doped stabilized ZrO in an oscillating mill, followed by high temperature calcination. This is great guidance for the subsequent preparation of HEOs. Notably, more efficient synthesis methods are emerging with the continuous development of science and technology. In addition to the solid-state reaction method, RE-HEOs can be prepared by pyrolysis, co-precipitation, and solution combustion. 3.1 Solid-state reaction method The solid-state reaction method (SRM) has become widely studied for producing high entropy materials by mixing and thoroughly grinding five or more metal oxides or metal salts as raw materials [57–59]. This ensures uniform distribution of the elements. One of the most typical methods is ball-milling synthesis, where mechanical energy is used to promote physical and chemical transformations (Fig. 4(a) ) [60,61]. It has been applied in large-scale synthesis due to its advantages of simple process, cost-effective, and pollution-free. Xue et al. [62] synthesized (La0.2Nd0.2Sm0.2Eu0.2Gd0.2)2Ce2O7 bulk by a two-step SRM (Fig. 4(b)). They mixed solid powders of metal oxides in stoichiometric ratio with anhydrous ethanol. The process involved ball-milling the mixture for 24 h, followed by drying at 70 °C. The resulting product was collected by sieving and pre-sintered at various temperatures. Pure phase HEO structure can be obtained under high temperature pre-sintering conditions, indicating the importance of synthesis conditions for the formation of single-phase HEOs. Anhydrous ethanol, as a control agent, can prevent powder oxidation, reduce surface energy, and promote subsequent drying [63]. Other commonly used control agents in ball-milling include stearic acid, solid paraffin, and others [64]. These agents can prevent powder agglomeration, maintain dispersion, reduce impurities, lower surface energy to speed up the ball milling process, and also perform in-situ surface modification [65]. The duration of ball milling is a crucial factor that affects the structure, size, and properties of the powder [66]. Longer ball milling time generates more energy, but it could also lead to oxidation, contamination, and agglomeration of the powder, which would adversely affect the material’s performance [67]. Therefore, it is essential to carefully control the ball-milling time to get the desired properties and avoid some adverse effects. SRM is capable of preparing bulk materials of HEOs with varying crystal structures. Simple ball-milling can make the powder structure uniform and provide a solid foundation for the synthesis and preparation of HEOs. However, the long-time, high-temperature heat treatment process (high energy consumption) limits the size of the powder particles (sintering is unavoidable), and susceptibility to contamination of the ball milling method needs to be further optimized and improved. By utilizing plasma-assisted ball milling technology, it is possible to modify the surface of high entropy oxide catalysts at lower temperatures, thus advancing composite material synthesis technology. The plasma field activates the raw material powder to make the powder finer. The rapid heating effect causes micro-zone sintering and micro-zone melting on the surface of the powder, which increases the active sites of the solid-state reaction of the material, accelerates the mass-transfer process, and improves the sintering activity [68]. Compared with traditional ball milling, plasma-assisted ball milling reduces the single-phase synthesis temperature of high-entropy ceramics. The grain growth of the particles is complete, and the density and mechanical properties are improved [69]. 3.2 Nebulized spray pyrolysis Spray pyrolysis is used to produce oxide powder of nearly nanometer size with high uniformity in terms of element distribution and purity. In this process, a metal salt solution is prepared as the HEO precursor according to the stoichiometric ratio of the target compound [70,71]. Atomize the solution through the atomizer and then carry the droplet to the reactor in the form of high-temperature gas (Fig. 5(a)). The process involves the evaporation of solvent, pyrolysis of solute, precipitation of particles, sintering, and molding in an instant (Fig. 5(b) ). The content and distribution of each element are highly uniform, and high-purity products can be obtained in a short time, which is an ideal means for the preparation of HEOs and is conducive to large-scale industrialized production. Djenadic et al. [45] used NSP to synthesize nanocrystalline multi-component HEO powders, and the elements were uniformly distributed in the lattice. Rare earth nitrate solutions were sprayed into droplets and mixed with oxygen in a hot-wall reactor, including Ce, Gd, La, Nd, Pr, Sm, and Y as precursors for different combinations. The stability of the oxide structure is influenced by the type of element in the high entropy system (elemental oxidation state), the grain size, and the synthesis process. Furthermore, the multi-component systems without Ce4+ have difficulty forming single-phase structures, regardless of the heat treatment conditions, demonstrating that Ce4+ plays an important role in stabilizing single-phase HEOs. Chellail et al. [72] used the same method to prepare three types of HEO systems. The morphology of the synthesized HEO powders is solid spheroids and hollow spheroids with an average particle size of 500 nm (Figs. 5(c)–(e)). Atom probe tomography (APT) precision technology provides 3D element distribution maps of the samples, which confirm that the metal ions in the three types of HEO systems are uniformly distributed at the atomic level (Fig. 5(f)). The uniform distribution of high configurational entropy components promotes the formation of single-phase solid solution structures, leading to a stable state in the system. This result serves as a strong foundation for the thermodynamic development of HEOs synthesized by NSP. Spray pyrolysis technology offers significant benefits, including simplicity, efficiency, high sample purity, and high dispersion, which have excellent practical value for production and application. However, this method has strict requirements for equipment and operation, and agglomeration is inevitable at high temperatures [73]. The conditions of high temperature and vacuum have a significant impact on the morphology and dispersion of powders [74]. These problems need to be further studied and improved. 3.3 Chemical Co-precipitation synthesis Chemical co-precipitation synthesis involves mixing various metal ions (metal salt solution) and adding a precipitant (e.g., NaOH) to the solution [75,76]. This process causes the metal ions to precipitate simultaneously by adjusting the pH or temperature of the solution, forming metal hydroxides or metal oxides. This simple and cost-effective method of synthesizing uniformly distributed particles in size is suitable for the preparation of multi-component HEO materials. He et al. [77] prepared (CrMnFeCoCu)3O4 nanoparticles by CCS, adding NaOH as a precipitant to the precursor solution (Fig. 6(a) ). The choice of precipitant directly affects the properties and quality of the final product. NaOH can form insoluble hydroxide precipitation with most metal ions, which also has high requirements for precipitation speed and uniformity [78]. Okejiri and colleagues [46] used a simple ultrasonic-mediated co-precipitation method to synthesize crystalline powder without calcination (Fig. 6(b)). The synthesized ultra-small particles of HEOs nanocrystals have a single-phase fluorite structure with high surface area and high oxygen vacancy concentration, which exhibit ultra-high stability and sintering resistance. Such nanocrystalline HEOs can be obtained sonochemically under ambient conditions and without the unfavorable heat-treatment process encountered in other synthetic strategies. The high-energy environment and acoustic cavitation of ultrasound can make the reactants mix uniformly and promote ion diffusion to form a new phase [79]. This technically feasible, simple, and scalable synthesis strategy offers great promise for the synthesis of nanostructured HEO systems with functional features. An et al. [80] used a combination of co-precipitation and calcination processes to construct hierarchical porous structure HEO materials by mixing nitrate solutions of La, Y, Gd, Sm, Nd, and Zr at the molar ratio of 1:1:1:1:5 (Fig. 6(c)). Mixing Ca2+ to form a gel network and grow ice crystals, which laid the foundation for the porous structure after freeze-drying and atmospheric pressure sintering. This process enables the synthesis of highly homogeneous and specific surface area HEOs with controllable pore size distribution at lower temperatures, which helps reduce energy consumption in the preparation process. The ultrasound-assisted synthesis process eliminates the need for unfavorable heat treatment processes to obtain final samples. The controllable synthesis of catalyst morphology in combination with unique preparation methods is also of great significance. Although the CCS method is simple to operate, sometimes the solubility product of the target product and impurity are similar. It is not possible to realize the complete separation, thus affecting the purity of the product, so it is necessary to strictly grasp the information about product separation during preparation to improve production efficiency [81]. 3.4 Solution combustion synthesis Solution combustion synthesis (SCS) is a wet chemical synthesis method that has gained popularity in recent years. The process requires low temperature and short duration to produce a small and well-mixed sample powder (Fig. 7(a) ). SCS is a superior choice for the preparation of HEO materials compared to other synthesis methods that have high energy consumption and complex operations [82]. During the synthesis process, a mixed metal salt solution is used as a precursor, and a reducing agent (e.g., urea and citric acid) is used as a fuel, which is miscible in appropriate proportions. It triggers a redox reaction under hot conditions, generating a large amount of exothermic gas and initiating combustion. Cong et al. [83] have successfully synthesized ultra-high entropy rare earth oxide (UHE-REO) containing 16 REs using the SCS method. Urea, as an incendiary agent, decomposes into NH3 and CO2 at high temperatures, releasing large amounts of heat energy and leading to the combustion of the solution [84,85]. The incendiary agent not only provides heat to the system but also ensures the formation of stable complexes with metal ions, increasing their solubility and preventing selective precipitation of metal ions during dehydration [84,86]. Furthermore, the decomposition of urea results in the formation of many holes in the solid product, which is beneficial for the preparation of porous materials [87]. In the same way, Salian et al. [88] synthesized the F-HEO (Ce0.2La0.2Pr0.2Sm0.2Y0.2)O1.6–δ at low temperature (500 °C). Under heating at 500 °C, the solvent evaporates to form a gel, which is further burned without a flame and gradually transformed into a sample powder (Fig. 7(b)). The samples obtained at 500 °C have formed the HEO structure, but the secondary phase is still present, and single-phase HEO was obtained by increasing the calcination temperature to 1000 °C. It is observed that increasing the temperature promotes the reduction of ΔG mix, leading to the formation of single-phase structures. The SCS process is a cost-effective method that utilizes the exothermic effect of the redox reaction to promote combustion and obtain a high-purity powder product. The high heating rate caused by combustion may also enhance the activity of the product by promoting the formation of some metastable phases. However, the combustion process has certain limitations, as it can lead to uncontrollable shaping of the final product, which needs to be further optimized and improved. 4 Application of RE-HEOs in catalysis The issues of environment and energy are closely interrelated, and it has been found that catalytic technologies have been widely researched and applied to alleviate such problems. HEOs have attracted considerable attention in catalysis for energy and the environment due to their unique structural features and exceptional stability [89]. It is worth noting that RE-HEOs, especially perovskite-type oxides, have been extensively researched in catalysis and have displayed exceptional performance. For instance, RE-HEOs are highly valuable in eliminating hazardous substances in the environment and in the photocatalytic degradation of azo dyes in water [90]. Additionally, HEOs containing transition metals and REs developed by researchers exhibit excellent resistance to water vapor and SO2 in high-temperature environments [91]. This section will present the applications of RE-HEOs in electrocatalysis, thermocatalysis, and photocatalysis in recent years. 4.1 Application of RE-HEOs in electrocatalysis Oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) and oxygen extraction reaction (OER) are critical conversion reactions in metal-air batteries and fuel cells, which serve as an energy conversion and storage system. Traditional Pt-based catalysts have good catalytic activity [92]. However, their high cost, low reserves, poor stability, and susceptibility to CO poisoning are significant obstacles to their large-scale industrial application. The entropic effect and abundant surface defects of HEOs lead to their excellent electrocatalytic performance. Their tunable electronic structure can adjust the binding energy of metal and oxygen, thus enhancing their electrocatalytic performance [93]. In addition, the unique electronic structure characteristics of rare earth ions can also effectively control the bonding strength between reaction intermediates and metal active sites. At the same time, the electronic orbital structure of rare earths exhibits excellent electron transfer ability and reduces the electron transfer energy, which plays an important role in improving the electrocatalytic activity [94,95]. Therefore, RE-HEOs are worth further exploration as catalysts for electrochemical reactions. Li et al. [96] reported an HEO nanoparticle catalyst with up to 10 metal-element combinations (Hf, Zr, La, V, Ce, Ti, Nd, Gd, Y, and Pd) uniformly dispersed on carbon black. The high temperature and rapid synthesis method ensured the formation of a homogeneous HEO structure from the multi-element mixture, avoiding the agglomeration of the nanoparticles and keeping them highly dispersed. Compared with the linear sweep voltammetry tests of commercial electrocatalysts Pd/C, Pd/C, and PdO/C, 10-HEO/C showed a higher half-wave potential at 0.85 V. The catalyst maintained 86% of the initial current after 100 hours (Fig. 8(a) ). The results indicate that oxidized Pd and oxygen defects are the main active sites, and the other nine elements exert a synergistic effect to stabilize Pd in the single-phase oxide structure. The design of this catalyst employs HEOs with ultra-multiple elemental composition, which reduces the amount of Pd, lowers the cost of use, and improves atomic utilization. This provides a new approach for the preparation of high entropy nanoparticles as efficient electrocatalysts. In addition, in catalysts that commonly use metallic Pd as the active site, the lower electronegativity of rare earth elements is more likely to give electrons and fill the antibonding orbitals of Pd to make Pd more metallic [97,98]. Thus, RE-HEOs are more promising for improving ORR activity. Patel et al. [99] conducted a study on the OER activity of single-crystal films made from (La0.2Pr0.2Nd0.2Sm0.2Eu0.2)NiO3 and grown on NdGaO3 substrates. The study aimed to determine the relationship between the thickness of the film and its OER catalytic activity. The research team systematically compared the onset potential, current density, and other parameters of the material and concluded that a high entropy single-crystal film with a thickness of 75 unit cell exhibited the highest OER catalytic activity (Fig. 8(b)). It was discovered that this improvement was attributed to the increase in Ni3d -O2p covalency and the decrease in charge transfer energy, which facilitates the charge transfer between Ni and the adsorbed substances on the surface. Furthermore, an in-depth exploration revealed that the thermodynamic transformation of REs both magnetically and structurally may affect splitting and defects in the Ni electronic orbitals, thus favoring the improvement of OER activity [100–102]. Ji et al. [103] have developed a method to enhance the electrocatalytic performance of high entropy perovskite oxides for OER by introducing Ca2+ doping at the A-site. They optimized the doping concentration and produced La0.6Ca0.4(CrMnFeCo2Ni)O3, which exhibited high activity and durability (Fig. 8(c)). It was further found that the introduction of Ca2+ resulted in abundant oxidation states of transition metal ions at the B-site, leading to a change in the electronic configuration in HEOs. Ca2+ doping also generated more surface oxygen vacancies, which enhanced the adsorption of oxygen-containing substances and increased conductivity, thus accelerating the OER kinetics. Furthermore, the increased conformational entropy due to Ca2+ doping may also effectively improve the catalytic reactivity. When La in the A-site of perovskite is replaced by Ca or Sr, i.e., trivalent (La3+) ions are replaced by divalent ions (Ca2+, Sr2+), a compensatory process has to take place in order to maintain charge neutrality. This can lead to the formation of tetravalent cobalt ions and oxygen defects, which have the advantage of increasing oxygen mobility and enhancing redox properties, thus making it easier to reduce [104]. 4.2 Application of RE-HEOs in thermocatalysis HEOs exhibit excellent catalytic effects in thermocatalytic reactions due to their abundance of active sites, adjustable specific surface area, and stable crystal structure. These properties are achieved through the combination of multiple cations. The CO oxidation reaction is an important research direction to deal with environmental problems. Converting CO to CO2 is a widely studied way to effectively reduce the serious damage caused by toxic gases, and thermocatalytic conversion is a feasible way to achieve this goal. Developing suitable catalysts to improve the efficiency of CO conversion can further promote the sustainable use of energy and improve economic and production efficiency. Although transition metal cations are able to enhance CO oxidizing activity by combining different elements, the thermal stability leaves much to be desired. Rare earth cations are likely to prevent thermal deactivation while helping to maintain activity [105]. Riley et al. [105] used the sol-gel method to optimize the synthesis of a Ce0.8(LaMnNdZr)0.2O2–y material with a high specific surface area. The material was synthesized by regulating the cationic composition and structure of Ce-based multi-element without any precious metals (Fig. 9(a)). Compared with the solid-state synthesis method, the catalyst synthesized by the sol-gel method has a larger specific surface area (Fig. 9(b) ) [106]. The Ce0.8(LaMnNdZr)0.2O2–y sample was observed to remain stable even after aging and exhibited high catalytic activity (Fig. 9(c)). The researchers found that catalysts with low activity are characterized by poor oxygen migration and oxygen storage capacity, which is caused by inadequate selection of cations. This is due to the transition metal cations providing higher activity and the introduction of REs stabilizing the main CeO2 lattice structure, preventing thermal deactivation of the catalyst during the reaction. This kind of facilitation between specific constituent elements that are favorable for the reaction to proceed provides a feasible idea for the design and development of HEO catalysts with the addition of REs. Li et al. [107] conducted a study on multi-element hybrid materials with different oxidation potentials from the perspectives of temperature-, oxidation- and entropy-driven. A high entropy oxide (ZrCe)0.6(MgLaYHfTiCrMn)0.3Pd0.1O2–x with a single-phase stable structure was obtained by rapid synthesis and screening (Fig. 9(d)). The traditional PdO x catalyst used for methane combustion was deactivated due to the sintering of nanoparticles and the conversion of PdO x to metallic Pd during the reaction process. Notably, this new catalyst can stabilize Pd in the cationic state within the high entropy structure, which improves the overall stability of the catalyst, resulting in no significant deactivation in catalyzing methane combustion for more than 100 h (Fig. 9(e)). Other studies have shown that the addition of rare earth element Y can inhibit the site growth and decomposition of PdO particles, thus improving the reduction-reoxidation properties of PdO actives and enhancing the catalytic activity and thermal stability [108]. Soot combustion catalytic reaction is also a process that converts harmful substances into harmless ones or reduces the amount of harmful substances, thus reducing their impact on the environment and human health. Duan et al. [109] successfully synthesized 3DOM-HEO by introducing three-dimensional ordered macroporous structures into HEO through self-assembly behavior (Fig. 9(f)). They applied this material to soot combustion to explore their catalytic activity (Fig. 9(g)). Among the prepared catalysts, 3DOM-HEO-CeO x showed excellent redox ability. The lattice distortion caused by multi-element doping increased the oxygen vacancy concentration, which improved its catalytic performance [109,110]. The catalytic activity remained unchanged in both the water resistance test and the simulated diesel exhaust gas test, proving that the high entropy structure remained structurally stable under harsh catalytic conditions and possessed excellent water vapor and sulfur resistance properties (Fig. 9(h)). These performances were due to the entropy stabilization effect and the establishment of three-dimensional ordered macroporous structures in the synthesized RE-HEOs catalysts. These findings provide valuable insight into the structural design and rational application of HEO catalysts. REs have unique properties such as redox activity, high oxygen mobility, and the ability to store and release oxygen. These properties make them useful in providing an oxygen-rich environment for the catalyst, promoting the activation of oxygen molecules, and enhancing their interaction with adsorbed soot. This facilitates the initiation of combustion reactions on the soot surface at lower temperatures than conventional thermal oxidation processes [111,112]. 4.3 Application of RE-HEOs in photocatalysis The production of textiles, dyes, and other industrial products has resulted in severe water pollution, which can be harmful to human health if not treated properly. Methylene blue (MB) is one of the major pollutants in water and can cause irreversible damage to the eyes of living beings. The process of photocatalysis has shown significant advantages in the degradation of dyes. In addition to the dye degradation, the photocatalytic decomposition of water to produce hydrogen is also an environmentally friendly means of energy acquisition [113]. Nanostructured CeO2 is considered an effective photocatalyst, but its catalytic activity is limited due to its wide band gap and low carrier mobility [114–116]. Some composite materials such as Ti, Zn, Bi, Cu, and other composite oxide semiconductors have been used as effective photocatalysts due to their photochemical stability, high conductivity, and high valence band energy [117]. RE-HEOs are also excellent photocatalysts [39,118]. Rare earth elements can generate abundant electronic energy levels and form unique electron leaps, significantly improving the photocatalyst’s activity. The doping of rare earth ions also generates vacancy defects in the catalyst surface and the newly formed oxygen vacancies can trap photoelectrons, form transition states and new energy levels between the energy level structures, enhance the light absorption range and effectively limit the compounding of photogenerated electrons and holes [119]. In addition, the formation of defects on the catalyst surface can enhance its adsorption capacity for reactants and generate more free radicals, thus improving the photocatalytic activity [120]. Nundy et al. [121] investigated the use of HEOs with a fluorite structure (Fig. 10(a) ), specifically Ce0.2Zr0.2La0.2Pr0.2Y0.2O2 (CZLPY), in photocatalytic degradation of azo dyes and water splitting in hydrogen generation, which showed high catalytic activity. The researchers found that these materials have suitable band gaps, conduction bands, and valence band energy levels, which give them high photocatalytic activity (Fig. 10(b)). CZLPY catalyst could produce hydrogen efficiently (9.2 μmol mg−1 h−1), significantly more than pure CeO2 material (0.8 μmol mg−1 h−1). In addition, the materials showed excellent degradation properties for a wide range of dyes and good reusability (Fig. 10(c)). They reported that the phase stabilization of HEO catalysts promoted more lattice distortion and higher oxygen vacancy concentration, which suggested valuable research ideas for RE-HEO materials in photocatalysis [122–124]. The issue of global climate change has received a lot of attention and research, particularly about CO2 conversion. Photocatalytic CO2 conversion can efficiently and cleanly convert CO2 into valuable hydrocarbon fuels while requiring low energy, which is crucial for sustainable energy development [125]. Wang et al. [126] reported a RE-HEO La(FeCoNiCrMn)O3 (LFCNCM) catalyst, which can be integrated to utilize the simultaneous photocatalytic redox production from CO2 reduction and biomass upgrading system to realize the generation of CO and xylonic acid. It was found that the material catalyzed CO yield as high as 454.1 mmol g−1 with high selectivity for CO2 reduction (Fig. 10(e)). The optimal rate of CO precipitation (131.8 μmol g−1 h−1) and xylonic acid yield (63.9%) were determined through the optimization of the light environment and time (Fig. 10(f)). After cyclic testing, the CO precipitation rate and xylonic acid yield were maintained well, which proved that the high entropy perovskite has good stability. The LFCNCM catalysts exhibited excellent photoelectron-chemical performances due to the high entropy structure, which was able to reduce the Gibbs free energy, improve the stability and the crystallinity, and enable fast and effective charge transfer and separation (Fig. 10(d)). In conclusion, the novel RE-HEO materials have significantly progressed in photocatalysis due to their structural stability and band gap adaptability. By Eu doping, Liu et al. [127] improved the mechanical and photocatalytic properties of HEO (La0.2Nd0.2Sm0.2Gd0.2Y0.2)1.99Eu0.01Zr2O7 (Fig. 10(g)). Eu doping has enhanced the structural stability of the oxide at high pressure and has shown good thermal stability even after sintering at 1500 °C. The bulk modulus of the HEO has been increased due to the coexistence of two Eu ion valence states. The single Eu substitution is trivalent [128], but the Eu ion behaves bivalently in the Eu-O pair, which is a unique form of doping that can release crystal strain and improve structural stability. Under UV light, the appropriate doping concentration, smaller grain size, and wider light absorption range change the band gap and significantly improve the photocatalytic performance (Figs. 10(h) and (i)). This research provides valuable insights into designing and improving the mechanical and photocatalytic properties of high entropy oxides. In brief, RE-HEOs exhibit distinctive structural characteristics, including disordered chemical compositions and atomic distributions, and possess superior thermodynamic, crystal structure, and kinetic properties. As a result, they have found numerous applications in research involving electro/thermal/photo-catalysis for energy and environmental purposes. Furthermore, RE-HEOs can stabilize the dispersion of noble metals at high temperatures, thereby enhancing their catalytic performance. Even without the use of noble metals, RE-HEOs are capable of maintaining excellent catalytic performance and cyclic stability, making them highly promising materials for future catalytic technologies. 5 Conclusions and prospect In summary, we present the research progress on RE-HEOs in recent years. The RE-HEOs can be broadly categorized into perovskite-type, fluorite-type, and pyrochlore-type structures. The most commonly used synthesis methods we summarize are the solid-state reaction method, nebulized spray pyrolysis, chemical co-precipitation synthesis, and solution combustion synthesis. Among them, the solid-state reaction method has become the most used method to complete chemical conversion by mechanical energy ball milling by its simple operation characteristics. Solution combustion synthesis is a high entropy material synthesis technique that has recently emerged. It can sufficiently shorten the synthesis time and improve the synthesis efficiency through spontaneous combustion. RE-HEOs can play an excellent role in promoting catalytic reactions and have been studied and applied in the fields of electrocatalysis, thermocatalysis, and photocatalysis. HEOs have significant performance advantages in the field of catalysis due to their own entropy-driven single-phase structural stability and the increase of various oxygen vacancies and activated lattice oxygen caused by lattice distortion. The specific ionic radii and variable valence states of REs can bring adjustable defect sites to the catalyst structure to improve properties such as the conductivity of oxide ions. In particular, the structural stability can meet the demand for catalytic performance under harsh conditions, which makes it more suitable as a reliable material for industrial production applications. However, the explanation of the structure and catalytic mechanism of RE-HEOs is still to be improved, and many challenges still exist in the synthesis and catalysis. For example, (1) the synthesis method significantly affects the morphology and structure of RE-HEOs, and the mutual substitution of REs and cationic vacancies plays a key role in the catalyst’s structure and properties. Therefore, designing suitable and efficient synthesis strategies for exclusive structure modulation is of great research significance. (2) Existing conventional characterization techniques are no longer sufficient for the adequate study of RE-HEOs, and a combination of multiple characterization techniques or advanced characterization methods is needed to further explore the structural features and catalytic mechanism. This has an important and far-reaching impact on the rapid establishment of the research mechanism of this high entropy system and guides the future research methodology of RE-HEOs [26]. (3) Currently, the catalytic applications for RE-HEO materials need to be more affluent, and most studies are for functional devices. However, the complex structure of RE-HEOs can lead to a vast number of potential reactivity factors, which need to be further studied and explored. By observing the existing research, the structural diversity of RE-HEOs materials has broad application prospects in electrocatalysis and other fields. We believe that through further research and design, strengthening the precise regulation of RE-HEOs structure and in-depth analysis of reaction mechanism, we can give full play to the catalytic properties of RE-HEOs and make a further qualitative leap in the field of catalysis of high entropy systems. Xiao Wang received his BSc degree in Chemistry in 2008 from Jilin University. Then, he joined the group of Prof. Hongjie Zhang at Changchun Institute of Applied Chemistry, Chinese Academy of Sciences (CAS), and received his PhD degree in Inorganic Chemistry in 2013. His research focus is primarily on the fabrication of functional inorganic materials for heterogeneous catalytic reactions and energy-related applications. Shuyan Song received his BSc degree in Chemistry in 2003 and MSc in inorganic chemistry in 2006 both from Northeast Normal University. He joined the group of Prof. Hongjie Zhang at Changchun Institute of Applied Chemistry, Chinese Academy of Sciences (CAS), where he received his PhD in inorganic chemistry in 2009. He is working as a professor under the direction of Prof. Zhang at Changchun Institute of Applied Chemistry, CAS. His research focus is primarily on the development of porous functional materials for heterogeneous catalysis, proton conduction, chemical sensing and detection. Hongjie Zhang received his BSc degree from Peking University in 1978. He then worked as a research assistant in Changchun Institute of Applied Chemistry, where he received his MSc degree in Inorganic Chemistry in 1985. Then, he worked as an assistant professor at the same institute from 1985–1989. He then studied at Universite de Bordeaux I, Laboratoire de Chimie du Solide du CNRS (France), where he received his PhD degree in Solid State Chemistry and Materials Sciences in 1993. He joined Changchun Institute of Applied Chemistry, CAS, as a professor in 1994. His current research interests include lanthanide organic-inorganic hybrid materials, electroluminescent devices, functional nanomaterials, and the structure and properties of rare earth magnesium alloys.

coredata.dc:description: High entropy oxides have been regarded as one of the most promising catalysts. Their unique and diverse elemental compositions bring stable structures and abundant metal active sites to the catalysts. Notably, rare earth ions have similar radii, unique electron orbitals, and variable valence states. As a result, incorporating rare earth elements into high entropy oxides can effectively adjust the surface state of the catalyst, ultimately improving the structure and properties of the high entropy oxides. However, there is no systematic review on the development of rare earth-incorporated high entropy oxides. In this review, we target the structure, synthesis, and application of rare earth-incorporated high entropy oxides to summarize their research progress in catalysis in recent years. First, we provide an overview of three types of rare earth-incorporated high entropy oxides: fluorite-type, perovskite-type, and pyrochlore-type. Then, the main synthesis methods are discussed in detail, including solid-state reaction, nebulized spray pyrolysis, chemical co-precipitation, and solution combustion. Finally, we analyze the applications of this material in catalytic reactions and suggest possible challenges and solution strategies. It is concluded that this unique material has good prospects for development.
